well I think this is a very choppy
situation here I mean for different
members of the cabinet have suggested to
me today it would be better if Dominic
Cummings had already disappeared there
are about 40 Conservative MPs actually
on the record going public even in a
difficult environment for them to
suggest that he should quit many many
more of them have private deep unease
and I think the frustration is now not
so much about what he did or didn't do
but in part about the handling of all of
this and the way that it has developed
over the last couple of days we've had
this surreal experience in his press
conference yesterday and also many MPs
just simply relating what they are
hearing from their constituents them
talking about getting you know hundreds
even more than a thousand emails
expressing fury but it says a lot about
this administration that inside the very
tight-knit group around Boris Johnson in
number 10 they sense that this might
actually be them starting to move to the
other side of the storm they hope and
believe that perhaps some of the public
anger might be starting to fade away I
have to say some polls that are reported
and tomorrow's newspapers don't suggest
that that is necessarily the case but
inside Downing Street there is still
absolutely a conviction that the cost of
hanging on Saddam ik Dominic Cummings is
less than the cost politically and
personally to them would be to see him
walk or if he decided that it was time
to resign but we will see tomorrow Boris
Johnson is up for a grilling in front of
a group of senior MPs and I think it's
likely that there may well be some
tricky exchanges there but as far as
Downing Street is concerned there is no
budging in this moment but there is also
no denying that in this moment of a
national crisis they have been
distracted trying to keep up with a
fast-moving political crisis that for
many people inside their own party is a
source of huge frustration not least
because
was very much an own goal by one of
